repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
`LanguageTree:parse` is recursive, and calls
`LanguageTree:for_each_child`, which is also recursive.

That means that, starting from the third level (child of child of root), nodes will be parsed twice.

Which then means that if the tree is N layers deep, there will be ~2^N parses even if the branching factor is 1.

Now, why was the tree deepening with each character inserted? And why did this only regress in #24647? And why doesn't `:parse` ever get short-circuited by `:is_valid` (I think I have a guess for this one - `:parse_regions` never gets called)? These are mysteries for another time, maybe they also go away with this fix, maybe they don't.

Fixes: #25104

comment_data.body: Is this PR a signal that `for_each_child()` can actually cause problems, thus is another reason to remove `for_each_child` besides the fact that `for_each_child` is not a useful abstraction (it duplicates `pairs`)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -444,9 +444,9 @@ function LanguageTree:parse(range)
     range = range,
   })
 
-  self:for_each_child(function(child)
+  for _, child in pairs(self._children) do

comment_data.body:
No. `for_each_child` does not duplicate `pairs`, as unlike `pairs`, it is recursive.

The problem here is that `parse` is also recursive so it needs to only iterate direct children.

We internally use `for_each_child` in two other places:
- When applying text edits to all the trees
- When registering recursive callbacks
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -444,9 +444,9 @@ function LanguageTree:parse(range)
     range = range,
   })
 
-  self:for_each_child(function(child)
+  for _, child in pairs(self._children) do

comment_data.body:
> unlike `pairs`, it is recursive.

Then it's badly named. A better name is `foreach_descendant` or `traverse`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -444,9 +444,9 @@ function LanguageTree:parse(range)
     range = range,
   })
 
-  self:for_each_child(function(child)
+  for _, child in pairs(self._children) do

comment_data.body:
Upon inspection, 2/3 calls to `for_each_child` have a similar double recursion problem.

So you're right it probably is a bad API.

I still don't have the best idea of what shape the API should take atm so I'm not sure adding any churn here is worth it. I'll raise a PR to fix the internal stuff though.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -444,9 +444,9 @@ function LanguageTree:parse(range)
     range = range,
   })
 
-  self:for_each_child(function(child)
+  for _, child in pairs(self._children) do

comment_data.body: +1 to `for_each_descendant`. I was actually gonna make a PR with the exact same suggestion but then I got sidetracked...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -444,9 +444,9 @@ function LanguageTree:parse(range)
     range = range,
   })
 
-  self:for_each_child(function(child)
+  for _, child in pairs(self._children) do

comment_data.body: I wasn't gonna break `for_each_child`, just make an alias while putting a deprecation notice on the original name.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -444,9 +444,9 @@ function LanguageTree:parse(range)
     range = range,
   })
 
-  self:for_each_child(function(child)
+  for _, child in pairs(self._children) do

comment_data.body: There are existing "traverse" functions, that is probably a better name and convention if we are going to introduce a new function. Assuming this function is even needed (it seems like something that could be generalized for any object that has `:children`).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -444,9 +444,9 @@ function LanguageTree:parse(range)
     range = range,
   })
 
-  self:for_each_child(function(child)
+  for _, child in pairs(self._children) do

comment_data.body: `children` doesn't seem to be standardized yet but i agree with the idea. shorter name too. can put it in shared.lua maybe
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -444,9 +444,9 @@ function LanguageTree:parse(range)
     range = range,
   })
 
-  self:for_each_child(function(child)
+  for _, child in pairs(self._children) do

comment_data.body: similar to [python](https://docs.python.org/3/howto/sorting.html#key-functions) `sorted(..., key=...)` we could have `traverse(..., key=...)` where `key` decides the field that is recursed-into (and it could default to "children").
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -444,9 +444,9 @@ function LanguageTree:parse(range)
     range = range,
   })
 
-  self:for_each_child(function(child)
+  for _, child in pairs(self._children) do

comment_data.body:
Sure, that works.

It turns out that there are actually no more calls to this function, so we can deprecate for now. #25118
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -444,9 +444,9 @@ function LanguageTree:parse(range)
     range = range,
   })
 
-  self:for_each_child(function(child)
+  for _, child in pairs(self._children) do

comment_regular_data.body:
> And why doesn't :parse ever get short-circuited by :is_valid (I think I have a guess for this one - :parse_regions never gets called)?

The (in)validation logic still needs a lot of work and is probably the reason for most bugs in the languagetree.

title: fix(languagetree): remove double recursion in LanguageTree:parse
